Introduction

In accordance with the rules laid down by the individual professional bodies (i.e. Nursing and Midwifery Council, General Medical Council, General Dental Council, Health and Care Professions Council and the Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain), any health care professional will have to have theirname retained on any or all parts of the appropriate professional register to enable the individual to practice in that area.

Every professional is asked to recognise that, in accordance with the above statutory rules, if they do not renew their registration by the date given in their fee request notice, and pay the required fee, their name “shall be removed automatically from the Register”.
Failure to meet this requirement will result in withdrawal of the right to practice in a post which requires the holder to have their name entered on any or all parts of the Register.

However, where the Registrar knows that a person who has not paid the fee due is the subject of disciplinary investigation or proceedings, “they shall not remove the person from the Register until such time as the investigations or proceedings have been determined”.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Explain the importance of validating the registration of health care professionals prior to their appointment within the Trust.
Document the procedure of checking any registration renewal for employees holding health care professional roles and the process the Trust implements when this registration lapses.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Chief People and Organisational Development Director

The Chief People and Organisational Development Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes and training are available to ensure that the Trust employs, and continues to employ, only those qualified staff holding a current registration, which entitles them to practice. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forums as indicated in the document.
Chief Medical Director

The Chief Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary actions are taken in accordance with the policy if medical and dental employees fail to maintain current registration and a licence to practice.
Chief Nursing Officer

The Chief Nursing Officer is responsible for ensuring that the necessary actions are taken in accordance with the policy if nursing and midwifery employees, Allied Health Care professionals and health care scientists fail to maintain current registration.
Director of Workforce Services & Strategic Planning

The Director of Workforce Services and Strategic Planning is required to ensure that all staff in the People and Organisational Development Directorate are aware of their responsibilities under this policy and that the policy is disseminated appropriately through the intranet.

The Director is responsible for ensuring that agencies on the national procurement framework that are required to comply with the employment check standards of NHS Employers are used to cover short term gaps in the workforce.
This Director is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forums as indicated in the document.
HR Business Partners (HRBPs)

HRBPs are required to ensure that the Recruitment Administrators check registration status as part of the recruitment process, and maintain accurate records on electronic records and the Electronic Staff Record (ESR).

They are required to ensure that managers are provided with details of any member of their staff whose registration is due to expire and to ensure that all registered healthcare professional staff are suspended without pay in all instances where registration has lapsed or evidence of renewal is not available.
Administrators

Recruitment Administrators are required to ensure that registration checks are carried out during the recruitment process. They must record details of registration for all successful applicants / employees to enable the information to be captured and maintained the information on the Electronic Staff Record.
Recruitment Administrators must check all successful applicant details against the Alert Letter database. If an applicant is the subject of an alert letter, they must inform the Recruiting Manager.
Workforce ESR Administrators must maintain accurate records of registrations on electronic records and the Electronic Staff Record (ESR).
Head of Workforce Systems
The Head of Workforce Systems is required to provide a report each month to the HRBPs with details of registrations that are due to expire by the end of the following month.
All Heads of Departments/Managers

All Managers are responsible for ensuring that all registered healthcare professionals in their teams are reminded of their duty to maintain registration, check registration when a renewal is needed and take prompt action when this is the case. They must act promptly when advised that the registration of an employee has lapsed.

Where the manager has been informed of restrictions or conditions being placed on the registration of a healthcare professional in the team; the manager must ensure that all work undertaken is in accordance with the restrictions. The manager must seek further advice from the relevant professional lead and the HRBP in these instances.
Managers must use agencies on the procurement frameworks that comply with the recruitment checks required by NHS Employers. They must seek advice from the Resourcing Team as appropriate.
All registered healthcare professionals

All registered clinical professionals are required to ensure that their registration is current at all times (including during maternity leave) and produce evidence to that effect at appointment, at re-registration and at any other time as requested by the appropriate Manager and/or HR.

They are required to ensure that they do not work at any time that their registration has lapsed and be aware that any period during which their registration has lapsed will be treated as suspension with no pay.
They are required to keep their manager informed of any events that may affect the status of their registration, including restrictions, conditions, cautions, convictions etc.
Failure to do so may result in disciplinary action being taken not excluding dismissal. Repeated failure to maintain registration may also result in disciplinary action, not excluding dismissal.
Alert letters during the recruitment process / employment checks
Alert letters are issued to notify NHS Bodies and others about a registered health professional whose performance or conduct could place patients or staff at serious risk.
Before any unconditional offer of employment is made to any applicant, the Recruitment Team will check the alert notifications to see if the applicant is the subject of an Alert Letter.
Should any applicant be the subject of an alert letter then the advice of a member of the Senior Recruitment Team must be sought so that further advice can be taken.
The applicant is also responsible for advising the Trust if they have information regarding Alert Status. Failure to do so may result in the offer of employment being withdrawn.
Recruitment staff will receive training to ensure that they understand the sensitivities around verification of identity.
Checking registration status
It is the responsibility of each health professional to maintain the professional registration required to carry out their duties and continue their employment with the Trust.
The following websites will support in checking professional registrations and/or validating documentation provided:
Dentists  www.gdc-uk.org/ Doctors  www.gmc-uk.org/ Nursing  www.nmc-uk.org/ AHPs  www.hcpc-uk.org/
Pharmacists  https://www.pharmacyregulation.org/

For all agency workers, it will be the responsibility of the agency to ensure that the worker maintains registration. It is expected that agencies on the national Procurement frameworks are in compliance with the NHS Recruitment Standards and these will be used for temporary bookings.

Following the UK's exit from the EU, from st January 2021 there will be transitional arrangements for up to two years for the acceptance of EU qualifications by UK professional registration bodies. Please refer to the relevant website for details.
Failure to provide evidence of current registration

Failure at any time, of a health professional to remain appropriately qualified/ and or registered may lead to suspension from duty without pay, until proof of qualification is provided to the Trust, or ultimately termination of employment.
If, following a period of two weeks, proof of registration cannot be provided this may lead to disciplinary action, which could include dismissal for breach of contract.
This policy only concerns itself with upkeep of periodic registration and is not pertinent to situations where removal from the register may occur, i.e., as a result of disciplinary or other action
Supplementary information regarding professional registration
The General Medical Council

The General Medical Council state that, “To practice medicine in the UK all Doctors are required by law to be both registered and hold a licence to practice.” Renewal of registration is an annual process and is based on the anniversary date on which full registration was granted.
Licence to Practice

On  November 2009 the GMC introduced the licence to practice. To practice medicine in the UK all doctors are required by law to hold both registration and a licence to practice. This applies whether they practice full time, part time, as a locum, privately or in the NHS, or whether they are employed or self-employed. Licensing is the first practical step towards revalidation. This will require doctors to renew their licence to practice periodically. The purpose of revalidation will be to give patients regular assurance that doctors registered with a licence are up to date and fit to practice.
The Nursing and Midwifery Council

The Nursing and Midwifery Council states that registration must be renewed every year. Individuals will be sent a reminder from the NMC 45 days prior to registration expiry. It is the responsibility of the individual to advise the NMC of change of address details and to ensure their registration is renewed in good time to continue to practice, and that evidence of CPD provided to the NMC as required every 3 years.
The General Dental Council

The General Dental Council maintains the Dentists Register and the Rolls of Dental Auxiliaries (Dental Hygienists and Dental Therapists), by registering all those who wish to practise as dentists, dental hygienists or dental therapists and who hold the required qualifications.

Each year, a request for the Retention Fee for the following year is sent to every registered dentist and auxiliary. Practising dentistry whilst un-registered amounts to illegal practice under the 1984 Dentists Act.
The Royal Pharmaceutical Society/General Pharmaceutical Council

The Royal Pharmaceutical Society provides information on the eligibility of Pharmacists to practice in Great Britain. Only pharmacists holding full time or part time registration are eligible to practice. The Council has the regulatory powers.
The Health and Care Professions Council

In order to remain registered with the HCPC, registrants must continue to meet the standards that are set for this profession. These standards are how registrants' ‘fitness to practice' is determined. The standards include the following:
Character, Health, standards of proficiency, standards of conduct, performance and ethics, standards for continuous professional development and standards of education and training.
Training
No specific training requirements.

data.text: Approval and implementation

This policy has been reviewed and approved by the Policy Working Group and will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on the Trust Intranets. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.

This policy will be approved through the Joint Negotiation Committee. Staff will be notified of its publication and review through the Trust's Communication channels. It will be posted on the Trust intranet and a copy is held in the Policy Libraries within the Trust.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 4)
The Trust aim to design and implement services, policies, procedures, needs of our service, population and workforce, ensuring that none are placed at a disadvantage over others.
In order to meet these requirements, an equality impact assessment is used to assess all its policies, procedures and practices. This procedure was found to be compliant with this assessment.

Appendix 1: HR Department - procedure for checking professional registration
PRE-EMPLOYMENT
Interview and Pre-Employment Stage

Before the Trust offers appointment to any post requiring professional clinical registration or qualification, the applicant will be asked to provide original documentation to the HR Department to prove that they hold the required qualification(s) and are appropriately registered, as required by NHS Employment Check Standards.
Copies of registration documents will be retained by HR and will be annotated with the date the original document was seen and the identity of the person checking.

All required health related professional qualifications and registrations will be verified with the relevant regulatory body by a member of the Recruitment team and a record made of the outcome of the check and the information added to ESR.

It is the responsibility of the applicant to declare to the Trust – at the time of application, and at any time subsequent to and during employment – if they are subject to investigation by their regulatory body or if they have any restrictions placed on their practice.
The Trust will undertake periodic verification, direct with the relevant regulatory body, of the registration status of health professionals that it employs.

Where there is a delay in obtaining registration documentation as often happens with newly qualified nursing staff, employees can be signed on to the Payroll as unqualified support workers. Once registration has been obtained and the original documentation supplied to HR for verification, staff will be paid at the appropriate level and their pay backdated to the date shown on their registration documentation.
